expanded_description: Review questions consolidate understanding of energy concepts by testing comprehension and problem-solving skills across all topics in Chapter 5, from work and energy definitions to power, simple machines, mechanical advantage, and efficiency. Success requires both conceptual understanding and quantitative problem-solving ability.

core_concept.principle: Chapter 5 review integrates work (force × distance), kinetic energy (½mv²), potential energy (mgh for gravitational, ½kx² for elastic), conservation of energy (total energy constant), power (work/time or force × velocity), simple machines (force-distance trade-off), mechanical advantage (force multiplication), and efficiency (useful output / total input). Mastery requires understanding energy transformations, applying conservation principles, calculating MA and efficiency, and recognizing real-world applications.
core_concept.explanation:
This review synthesizes all energy topics covered in Unit 5:

**Work (5.1)**: Energy transfer via force causing displacement. $W = Fd\cos\theta$. Positive work adds energy, negative work removes energy. Only force component parallel to displacement does work.

**Kinetic Energy (5.2)**: Energy of motion. $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$. Depends quadratically on speed (double speed → 4× KE). Work-energy theorem: $W_{\text{net}} = \Delta KE$.

**Potential Energy (5.3)**: Stored energy from position/configuration. Gravitational: $PE_g = mgh$. Elastic: $PE_s = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$. Conservative forces allow PE definition. PE relative to chosen reference level.

**Conservation of Energy (5.4)**: Total energy constant in isolated system. For conservative forces only: $KE_i + PE_i = KE_f + PE_f$ (mechanical energy conserved). With friction: mechanical energy decreases (converts to heat), but total energy (including thermal) still conserved.

**Power (5.5)**: Rate of energy transfer. $P = W/t$ or $P = Fv$. Measured in watts (J/s). Same work done faster requires more power. Efficiency relates to power: $\eta = P_{\text{out}}/P_{\text{in}}$.

**Simple Machines (5.6)**: Six basic devices that change force magnitude/direction: lever, wheel and axle, pulley, inclined plane, wedge, screw. All trade force for distance: reduce force needed by increasing distance traveled. Work conserved (ideally): $F_{\text{in}}d_{\text{in}} = F_{\text{out}}d_{\text{out}}$.

**Mechanical Advantage (5.7)**: Force multiplication ratio. $MA = F_{\text{out}}/F_{\text{in}}$. Ideal MA (IMA) from geometry. Actual MA (AMA) from measured forces. Efficiency: $\eta = AMA/IMA$.

**Efficiency (5.8)**: Useful output / total input. $\eta = E_{\text{out}}/E_{\text{in}} = W_{\text{out}}/W_{\text{in}}$. Always ≤ 100% due to friction, heat losses. Difference is wasted energy (usually heat).

Success requires understanding energy as unifying concept connecting force, motion, and transformations throughout physics.

sections.introduction: Work is energy transfer through force causing displacement. Fundamental concept connecting force to energy.

key_concept.definition:
Work $W$ done by constant force: $W = Fd\cos\theta$ where $F$ is force magnitude, $d$ is displacement magnitude, $\theta$ is angle between force and displacement vectors.

Special cases: Parallel force ($\theta = 0°$): $W = Fd$ (maximum). Perpendicular ($\theta = 90°$): $W = 0$. Opposite ($\theta = 180°$): $W = -Fd$ (negative work).

Units: joules (J) = newton-meters (N·m). Work is scalar but can be positive, negative, or zero.
key_concept.context: Work quantifies energy transfer. Positive work adds energy to object (speeds up, lifts, compresses). Negative work removes energy (slows down, friction). Zero work when force perpendicular to motion (centripetal force, normal force on horizontal motion) or no displacement.

worked_examples.title: Work Calculation Review
worked_examples.problem: A 15 kg box is pushed 8 m across a floor. Applied force is 60 N at 25° above horizontal. Friction is 20 N. Find: (a) work by applied force, (b) work by friction, (c) net work.

step_by_step.explanation:
Force 60 N at 25° to horizontal displacement.
$W_{\text{applied}} = Fd\cos\theta = 60 × 8 × \cos 25°$
$\cos 25° \approx 0.906$
$W_{\text{applied}} = 60 × 8 × 0.906 = 435$ J (positive—component in motion direction)

Friction 20 N opposite to motion ($\theta = 180°$).
$W_{\text{friction}} = 20 × 8 × \cos 180° = 20 × 8 × (-1) = -160$ J (negative—opposes motion)

$W_{\text{net}} = W_{\text{applied}} + W_{\text{friction}} = 435 + (-160) = 275$ J
Net positive work → box gains 275 J kinetic energy (speeds up)

worked_examples.concept_applied: Work: $W = Fd\cos\theta$. Angled force—only parallel component does work. Friction always negative (opposes motion). Net work = algebraic sum.

sections.section_title: Section 5.2 Review: Energy and Kinetic Energy
sections.introduction: Kinetic energy is energy of motion. Work-energy theorem connects work to KE change.

key_concept.definition:
Kinetic energy: $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$ where $m$ is mass (kg), $v$ is speed (m/s). Units: joules (J).

Work-Energy Theorem: $W_{\text{net}} = \Delta KE = KE_f - KE_i = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f^2 - v_i^2)$

Net work equals kinetic energy change. Positive work → KE increases (speeds up). Negative work → KE decreases (slows down). Zero work → constant KE (constant speed).
key_concept.context: KE depends linearly on mass (double mass → double KE) but quadratically on speed (double speed → quadruple KE). This $v^2$ dependence crucial for safety (high-speed collisions far more dangerous). Work-energy provides alternative to force analysis—analyze initial/final energies instead of tracking forces throughout motion.

worked_examples.title: Work-Energy Application
worked_examples.problem: A 1000 kg car traveling at 20 m/s brakes with friction force 8000 N. Find stopping distance using work-energy theorem.

step_by_step.explanation: $KE_f = 0$ (stopped)

$W_{\text{net}} = \Delta KE = 0 - 200,000 = -200,000$ J
Friction must do -200,000 J of work (remove 200,000 J from car)

$W = -Fd$ (negative—friction opposes motion)
$-200,000 = -8000 × d$
$d = 200,000/8000 = 25$ m

worked_examples.concept_applied: Work-energy: All initial KE must be removed by friction work. $\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = Fd$ → $d = \frac{mv^2}{2F}$. Simpler than kinematics approach!

sections.introduction: Potential energy is stored energy from position or configuration. Associated with conservative forces.

key_concept.definition:
**Gravitational PE**: $PE_g = mgh$ where $m$ is mass (kg), $g = 9.8$ m/s², $h$ is height (m) above reference level.

**Elastic PE**: $PE_s = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$ where $k$ is spring constant (N/m), $x$ is displacement from equilibrium (m).

Both measured in joules (J). Gravitational PE relative to chosen reference (ground, floor, etc.). Elastic PE always positive (natural zero at equilibrium).
key_concept.context: PE is 'stored' energy—capacity to do work as position/configuration changes. Gravitational PE can do work as object falls. Elastic PE can do work as spring releases. PE ↔ KE transformations fundamental to energy conservation.

worked_examples.title: Potential Energy Calculations
worked_examples.problem: A 2 kg ball is held 5 m above ground. A spring ($k = 400$ N/m) is compressed 0.2 m. Find: (a) gravitational PE of ball, (b) elastic PE of spring, (c) total PE if both released simultaneously.

step_by_step.explanation:
Total PE = 98 + 8 = 106 J
If released simultaneously and no friction:
All converts to kinetic energy at ground level.
Ball: 98 J → KE at ground.
Spring's attached object: 8 J → KE when spring relaxed.
Total KE at end = 106 J (energy conserved)

worked_examples.concept_applied: PE stored in elevated position (gravitational) or deformed configuration (elastic). Can calculate total PE by adding different forms.

sections.introduction: Total energy constant in isolated system. For mechanical systems with conservative forces only, mechanical energy ($KE + PE$) conserved.

key_concept.definition:
**Conservation of Energy**: $E_{\text{total,i}} = E_{\text{total,f}}$

**Mechanical Energy Conservation** (conservative forces only):
$KE_i + PE_i = KE_f + PE_f$
$\frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 + mgh_i = \frac{1}{2}mv_f^2 + mgh_f$

**With friction**:
$KE_i + PE_i = KE_f + PE_f + Q$
where $Q$ is heat from friction ($Q = fd$).

Energy transforms between forms but total never changes.
key_concept.context: Most powerful principle in physics. Enables solving complex problems by comparing initial/final states without tracking forces throughout motion. Works for any path, any conservative force system. With friction: mechanical energy decreases (becomes heat), but total energy (mechanical + thermal) still conserved.

worked_examples.title: Conservation with Friction
worked_examples.problem: A 5 kg block slides from rest down a 30° ramp (height 4 m, length 8 m). Friction coefficient 0.15. Find speed at bottom using energy conservation.

step_by_step.explanation:
$KE_i = 0$ (starts from rest)
$PE_i = mgh = 5 × 9.8 × 4 = 196$ J
$E_i = 196$ J

Normal force: $F_N = mg\cos 30° = 5 × 9.8 × 0.866 = 42.4$ N
Friction: $f = \mu_k F_N = 0.15 × 42.4 = 6.36$ N
Heat: $Q = fd = 6.36 × 8 = 50.9$ J

Without friction: $mgh = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$ → $v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2 × 9.8 × 4} \approx 8.85$ m/s
With friction: 7.62 m/s (lower—some energy lost to heat)

worked_examples.concept_applied: With friction: Initial PE = Final KE + Heat from friction. Some energy dissipates, reducing final speed below frictionless case.

sections.section_title: Section 5.5 Review: Work, Energy, and Power
sections.introduction: Power is rate of energy transfer—how quickly work is done or energy is transformed.

key_concept.definition:
**Power**: $P = \frac{W}{t}$ (work per time) or $P = \frac{E}{t}$ (energy per time)

For constant force and velocity: $P = Fv$

Units: watt (W) = joule/second (J/s). Common: kilowatt (kW = 1000 W), megawatt (MW = 10⁶ W).

Energy from power: $E = Pt$. Electricity often measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh): 1 kWh = 3.6 MJ.
key_concept.context: Power distinguishes fast from slow processes with same energy. High power = rapid energy transfer. Two machines doing same work but different times have different power. Human sustained power ~100-200 W. Car engines ~100-300 kW. Power plants ~500-1000 MW.

worked_examples.title: Power Calculations
worked_examples.problem: A motor lifts 500 kg elevator 30 m in 20 seconds at constant velocity. Find: (a) work done, (b) power output.

step_by_step.explanation:
At constant velocity, upward force = weight
$F = mg = 500 × 9.8 = 4900$ N
$W = Fd = 4900 × 30 = 147,000$ J = 147 kJ

Velocity: $v = d/t = 30/20 = 1.5$ m/s
$P = Fv = 4900 × 1.5 = 7350$ W
Same result ✓

This is output power (useful work lifting elevator).
If motor 85% efficient: Input power = 7350/0.85 ≈ 8650 W = 8.65 kW.
Waste heat: 8650 - 7350 = 1300 W (15% lost to motor friction, resistance).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Power = work/time. Same work, less time → more power. Can also calculate from $P = Fv$ for constant force/velocity.

sections.introduction: Six classical simple machines trade force for distance, making work easier by reducing force needed (at cost of increased distance).

key_concept.definition:
**Six Simple Machines**: Lever, Wheel and axle, Pulley, Inclined plane, Wedge, Screw.

**Core Principle**: Trade force for distance. Reduce force required by increasing distance traveled. Work conserved (ideal): $F_{\text{in}}d_{\text{in}} = F_{\text{out}}d_{\text{out}}$

Cannot reduce work required (energy conservation), but can reduce force needed. Makes tasks achievable with available force by accepting longer distance/time.
key_concept.context: Simple machines don't create energy or reduce work—they redistribute it. Psychological/practical advantage: humans have force limits but can exert smaller forces over longer distances/times. Lever can lift car with small force by pushing long distance. All complex machines are combinations of simple machines.

worked_examples.title: Simple Machine Work Conservation
worked_examples.problem: An inclined plane is 12 m long, rises 3 m. Used to push 200 N box to top. Assuming frictionless: (a) What force needed parallel to ramp? (b) Distance pushed? (c) Work done? Compare to lifting vertically.

step_by_step.explanation:
Ramp IMA = length/height = 12/3 = 4
Force needed: $F = W/IMA = 200/4 = 50$ N
Much less than 200 N (vertical lift)!

Along ramp: 12 m (vs 3 m vertical).
4× longer distance.

Ramp: $W = Fd = 50 × 12 = 600$ J
Vertical: $W = mgh = 200 × 3 = 600$ J
Same work! Energy conservation.

Ramp: 50 N force (4× less), 12 m distance (4× more) → same 600 J work.
Vertical: 200 N force, 3 m distance → 600 J work.
Ramp makes task possible with smaller force available (trade distance for force).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Simple machines: Force reduced by MA factor, distance increased by same factor. Work conserved: $F_{\text{small}} × d_{\text{large}} = F_{\text{large}} × d_{\text{small}}$.

sections.introduction: Mechanical advantage quantifies force multiplication. Ideal MA from geometry, actual MA from measured forces.

key_concept.definition:
**Mechanical Advantage**: $MA = \frac{F_{\text{out}}}{F_{\text{in}}}$

**Ideal MA (IMA)**: From geometry. Assumes frictionless.
- Lever: $IMA = L_{\text{effort}}/L_{\text{load}}$
- Wheel/axle: $IMA = r_{\text{wheel}}/r_{\text{axle}}$
- Pulley: $IMA = n$ (number of supporting rope segments)
- Incline: $IMA = L/h$ (length/height)
- Wedge: $IMA = L/t$ (length/thickness)
- Screw: $IMA = 2\pi r/p$ (circumference/pitch)

**Actual MA (AMA)**: From measured forces. Always $AMA < IMA$ due to friction.

**Efficiency**: $\eta = AMA/IMA$
key_concept.context: MA tells how much machine multiplies force. MA > 1: force amplification (typical goal). MA = 1: direction change only. MA < 1: speed advantage (force disadvantage). Friction reduces actual MA below ideal—gap reveals losses.

worked_examples.title: MA and Efficiency
worked_examples.problem: A lever has 1.8 m effort arm, 0.3 m load arm. In use, 40 N effort lifts 200 N load. Find: (a) IMA, (b) AMA, (c) efficiency.

step_by_step.explanation: $AMA = \frac{F_{\text{out}}}{F_{\text{in}}} = \frac{200}{40} = 5$
$\eta = \frac{AMA}{IMA} = \frac{5}{6} \approx 0.833 = 83.3\%$

Geometry predicts MA = 6.
Friction reduces actual MA to 5 (16.7% loss).
Efficiency 83.3%—quite good for simple lever.
Could improve with better pivot bearing, lubrication.

worked_examples.concept_applied: IMA from geometry (ideal prediction). AMA from real forces (actual performance). Efficiency = AMA/IMA shows friction impact.

sections.introduction: Efficiency measures energy conversion effectiveness—fraction of input becoming useful output rather than waste.

key_concept.definition:
**Efficiency**: $\eta = \frac{E_{\text{out}}}{E_{\text{in}}} = \frac{W_{\text{out}}}{W_{\text{in}}} = \frac{P_{\text{out}}}{P_{\text{in}}}$

Always: $0 \leq \eta \leq 1$ (0% to 100%). Perfect efficiency (100%) impossible in real machines.

**Wasted energy**: $E_{\text{wasted}} = E_{\text{in}}(1 - \eta)$

**For simple machines**: $\eta = \frac{AMA}{IMA}$

**Compound systems**: $\eta_{\text{total}} = \eta_1 × \eta_2 × \eta_3 × ...$ (multiply individual efficiencies)
key_concept.context: Efficiency reveals how much energy is wasted (usually as heat from friction). High efficiency (>90%): electric motors, transformers, bicycles. Moderate (40-70%): diesel engines, LEDs, power plants. Low (<40%): gasoline engines (~28%), incandescent bulbs (~5%). Improving efficiency reduces energy costs, environmental impact. Often pays for itself through energy savings.

worked_examples.title: Efficiency and Operating Cost
worked_examples.problem: Two pumps deliver same 10 kW water flow. Pump A: 75% efficient. Pump B: 90% efficient. Cost difference if run 4000 hours/year at $0.10/kWh?

step_by_step.explanation:
Pump A: $13.33 × 4000 = 53,320$ kWh/year
Pump B: $11.11 × 4000 = 44,440$ kWh/year
Difference: 8,880 kWh/year

Savings with B: $8880 × 0.10 = \$888$/year
Over 20-year life: $888 × 20 = \$17,760$ savings!

If Pump B costs $500 more initially:
Payback time: $500/888 ≈ 0.56$ years ≈ 7 months.
After 7 months, pure savings. High-efficiency worth it!

worked_examples.concept_applied: Lower efficiency requires more input for same output → higher energy costs. Efficiency improvements often pay for themselves quickly through reduced operating costs.

summary:
**Unit 5 Review Summary**:

**Work (5.1)**: Energy transfer via force causing displacement. $W = Fd\cos\theta$. Parallel force → maximum work ($Fd$). Perpendicular → zero work. Opposite → negative work ($-Fd$). Positive work adds energy, negative removes energy. Only force component along displacement does work. Units: joules (J) = N·m.

**Kinetic Energy (5.2)**: Energy of motion. $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$. Linear dependence on mass, quadratic on speed (double speed → 4× KE—critical for safety). Work-energy theorem: $W_{\text{net}} = \Delta KE$. Net work equals KE change. Provides alternative to force analysis—compare initial/final energies instead of tracking forces.

**Potential Energy (5.3)**: Stored energy from position/configuration. Gravitational: $PE_g = mgh$ (relative to chosen reference level). Elastic: $PE_s = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$ (spring compression/stretch). Conservative forces allow PE definition. Work by conservative force = $-\Delta PE$. PE ↔ KE transformations fundamental.

**Conservation of Energy (5.4)**: Total energy constant in isolated system. For conservative forces only: $KE + PE = \text{constant}$ (mechanical energy conserved). $\frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 + mgh_i = \frac{1}{2}mv_f^2 + mgh_f$. With friction: mechanical energy decreases (converts to heat $Q = fd$), but total (mechanical + thermal) still conserved. Most powerful problem-solving principle—analyze initial/final states without tracking forces throughout.

**Power (5.5)**: Rate of energy transfer. $P = W/t$ (work per time) or $P = Fv$ (force × velocity). Units: watts (W) = J/s. Same work done faster requires more power. Distinguishes fast from slow processes. Energy from power: $E = Pt$. Electricity measured in kWh (kilowatt-hours = 3.6 MJ). Power ranges: human ~100-200 W, car engines ~100-300 kW, power plants ~500-1000 MW.

**Simple Machines (5.6)**: Six basic devices change force magnitude/direction: lever, wheel and axle, pulley, inclined plane, wedge, screw. Core principle: trade force for distance. Reduce force needed by increasing distance. Work conserved (ideal): $F_{\text{in}}d_{\text{in}} = F_{\text{out}}d_{\text{out}}$. Cannot reduce work (energy conservation), but make tasks achievable with available force. All complex machines are combinations of simple machines.

**Mechanical Advantage (5.7)**: Force multiplication ratio. $MA = F_{\text{out}}/F_{\text{in}}$. Ideal MA (IMA): from geometry, assumes frictionless. Formulas: Lever ($L_e/L_l$), Wheel/axle ($r_w/r_a$), Pulley ($n$ segments), Incline ($L/h$), Wedge ($L/t$), Screw ($2\pi r/p$). Actual MA (AMA): from measured forces, always $AMA < IMA$ due to friction. Efficiency: $\eta = AMA/IMA$ shows friction impact.

**Efficiency (5.8)**: Useful output / total input. $\eta = E_{\text{out}}/E_{\text{in}} = W_{\text{out}}/W_{\text{in}} = P_{\text{out}}/P_{\text{in}}$. Always ≤ 100%. Waste: $E_{\text{wasted}} = E_{\text{in}}(1-\eta)$, usually becomes heat. Typical ranges: Very high (>90%): electric motors, transformers. Moderate (40-70%): diesel engines, LEDs, power plants. Low (<40%): gasoline engines (~28%), incandescent bulbs (~5%). Improving efficiency: lubrication, better bearings, maintenance. Economic impact: higher efficiency → lower operating costs. Often pays for itself through energy savings. Environmental: less fuel → less pollution.

**Key Connections**: Work transfers energy. KE and PE store energy. Conservation constrains transformations (total constant). Power describes rate. Machines redistribute work (force-distance trade-off). MA quantifies force multiplication. Efficiency reveals losses. All interconnected through energy concept—unifying principle throughout physics. Success requires both conceptual understanding (why principles work) and problem-solving skills (applying formulas, calculating unknowns, interpreting results).
